text: So I think a lot of people recognise that that economic regulator role could be key, but that we wanted to know more. So we have gone away and done some research on it. So I'm going to quickly run through what we learned about economic regulators and how they operate in different sectors, both here and internationally, and then how that compares with what we currently know about the proposed economic regulator and these reforms.  We'll then run over some of the key questions that we have at this stage, which will hopefully help our thinking about the roles that we might like to see the economic regulator do in this proposed system.  OK, so firstly, I guess being part of Council, we'll all be familiar with regulators, which are entities authorised by statute to use legal tools to achieve policy objectives. So this is primarily through functions such as licensing, permitting, accrediting, approvals, inspection and enforcement.  However, economic regulators are mainly focused on addressing market failures and promoting competition where possible. They generally do this by putting in place arrangements to enable competition. So for example, that's deciding on who can enter an industry or market or making decisions on price. So think of things like price controls. So essentially the key thing that an economic regulator does is to ensure that monopolistic behavior doesn't occur.  Some sectors where economic regulators are common are electricity, both the generation and transmission of telecommunications, water, gas, roads, rail and airports.  So in addition to controlling prices, the other most common functions for economic regulators are access regulations. So that's placing an obligation on infrastructure providers to provide access to a service. Monitoring, that's through providing information on profitability and quality of service to government and stakeholders. Another one is dispute resolution. So that's things like arbitrating and resolving disputes over prices and services provided.  And then the last one is some economic regulators are also involved in setting standards. So an example of that might be setting quality for drinking water. OK, so what do we know about the proposed economic regulator and the free water space? Well, we know that ministers have agreed that the free water sector will be subject to economic regulation, and the purpose of that is to ensure that there's a good quality  of service for the consumer and to drive efficiency gains and then protect against inefficiencies. So again, that's, I guess, thinking of setting prices. The legislation is also to ensure the right level of investment, to meet depreciation, and then to remove those opportunities for monopoly behavior and excessive pricing. So really strong on that one.  Okay, so I think, as was mentioned earlier in the presentation, there's going to be that paper that the Three Waters Steering Group is going to release later this year. And what we know is that the topics that's likely to be covered in that paper  the design of an appropriate dispute resolution process, the establishment of a consumer advocacy council or the extension of an existing body to provide expert advocacy on behalf of consumers, options to protect consumers who are vulnerable due to their age, health, disability or financial position, an ability for a regulator to mandate service quality codes,  and the process for setting prices, including requirements for pricing transparency. So all of those things there that are outlined in what the ministers say will be in the legislation, and then in that paper, they all align exactly with the roles and functions that you might expect any standard economic regulator would play.  It's also worth mentioning that the economic regulator would be part of that wider regulatory group. So as you can see on your screen there, alongside Taumata Atawai and the regional councils.  So from that, it seems the economic regulator would primarily be looking to ensure those positive economic outcomes, while those other regulatory bodies may be more responsible for some of the other well-being outcomes, the environmental, social and cultural ones, although there's much overlap between all of those, yeah, those different areas. So one of the key things we wanna know more about is how they're all gonna work together and align their planning and their decision-making  And I guess the other main question we have is, as I'm sure everyone else does, is how do we ensure that that local voice is heard? So to bring us back to the purpose of this workshop, which is identifying what we support and where further detail or information or explanation will be useful, I'll just go through some starters for 10 for thinking about the economic regulator from a staff perspective.  So as staff, we're generally supportive of the potential functions of an economic regulator, as they've been described in the information that we have to date, that all those potential functions do seem to align well with the best practice.  We think that expanding the scope of the economic regulator beyond pricing is probably useful. And we know that that's something that seems to be under consideration because it's going to be talked about in that discussion paper under that topic of the ability for regulators to mandate service quality codes. So we think that's probably a good thing as it might help ensure that multiple well-beings are provided for and not just that financial economic well-being.  However, we know that Taumata Arawai will be involved in service quality too. So any overlap between those different regulators will need to be worked through. And that's where we think aligned strategic planning between the various stakeholders in the system will be key.  We think the economic regulator is likely to be national. So there won't be separate economic regulators for each individual water service entity. And we think that's probably right. It does align with how Scotland's seemingly successful system works. And in Australia, they seem to have the economic regulators at the state level. So that generally lines up with what's being proposed here if you compare things on a population level basis.  One thing we're keen to know more about is that potential consumer advocacy council. So firstly, who would be on that group? And could it be the same people that are involved in any of the other layers of the system?  And is there going to be one consumer advocacy council for each water service entity, or will that also be national? As staff, we think it's important that there's one consumer advocacy council for each water service entity, so four of them, because we think that could help provide for that local voice.  We'd also like to explore the idea of having an ombudsman play a role in this proposed system. We like the idea of it because it's a model that people are already familiar with and it operates well in other sectors. It also provides another tool for that consumer voice and the resolution of complaints. And it also provides for that fair, independent and quick process.  OK, another thing is that we'd like some certainty that the economic regulator would ensure that principle of growth pays for growth the same way that many other councils do, including ours. And two more things here.  We know that there's that statement of strategic and performance expectations to be drafted, and this is going to place a requirement on the board to report to the representative group. So a question we'd like to explore is whether that statement, the statement of strategic and performance expectations, could include a provision to formalise a link back to the local authorities, ideally each one individually with the water service entity.  And that link could also require consideration of LGA plans, such as annual plans and long-term plans, and even non-statutory plans like a spatial plan. So yeah, that's it from me at this stage. I'll hand back to you, Dawn.
